attributes.title: Institutional Sources of Legitimacy for International Organizations

q1.value: Institutional Sources of Legitimacy for International Organizations

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This study explores how institutional qualities of international organizations (IOs) affect their perceived legitimacy. It builds on and extends a stream of research interested in the causal significance of institutional qualities as sources of legitimacy for IOs (Bechtel and Scheve 2013; Bernauer and Gampfer 2013; Anderson et al. 2018; Scholte and Tallberg 2018; Dellmuth, Scholte, and Tallberg 2019; Tallberg and Zürn 2019). This literature tends to explore how institutional qualities related to procedures and performances affect the legitimacy of IOs. On the procedural side, research examines how conformance to qualities such as participation, efficiency, and impartiality affects legitimacy perceptions. On the performance side, research examines the importance for legitimacy of qualities such as problem-solving, welfare gains, and distributive justice. This study moves beyond earlier research in two respects. First, it integrates the political authority and the organizational purpose of an IO as a third and fourth institutional quality potentially affecting its perceived legitimacy. This is based on the intuition that people might not only evaluate IOs based on their procedures and performances, but also based on their level of political authority (Zürn 2018) and their organizational missions or mandates (Scott 1991; Lenz and Viola 2017). Authority and purpose might generate or reduce legitimacy in and of themselves, irrespective of an IO’s other institutional qualities. Second, it uses a conjoint design to estimate the causal effects of multiple institutional qualities simultaneously (see also Bechtel and Scheve 2013). It thereby seeks to move beyond limitations in vignette experiments, which currently dominate the study of how institutional qualities affect the legitimacy of IOs.

q16.value: We operationalize legitimacy beliefs using the measure of confidence in IOs. In the conjoint experiment, respondents were shown comparisons of two hypothetical IOs and then asked to respond to three questions measuring their confidence in these IOs: - Which organization would you have most confidence in? [Organization 1 or Organization 2] - If both organizations existed, how much confidence would you have in organization 1? [No confidence at all (0) to Complete confidence (10)] - If both organizations existed, how much confidence would you have in organization 2? [No confidence at all (0) to Complete confidence (10)] The second and third questions both serve to validate the choice made in the first question and to offer a more fine-grained measure of the level of confidence. The experiment tests four hypotheses about effects of institutional qualities on the perceived legitimacy of IOs. The four hypotheses are linked to authority, purpose, procedure, and performance as sources of legitimacy, and operationalized through six measures. H1: Concerns with the political authority of IOs affect their perceived legitimacy. - Operationalization: The extent to which the IO has power over member countries. H2: Concerns with the social purpose of IOs affects their perceived legitimacy. - Operationalization: The type of societal problem the IO works to address. H3: Concerns with the procedures of IOs affect their perceived legitimacy. - Operationalization 1: The extent to which information about IO decision-making is public. - Operationalization 2: The type of actors who have a say in IO decision-making. H4: Concerns with the performance of IOs affect their perceived legitimacy. - Operationalization 1: The extent to which the benefits from IO decisions benefit all. - Operationalization 2: The extent to which IO decisions solve important problems.

q17.value: We devised a fully-randomized conjoint experiment in which each respondent is shown two IOs in comparison and asked to choose between them. Each respondent receives four such screens. Each screen compares two hypothetical IOs and asks the respondent to choose between them and to indicate his/her level of confidence in them. The order of the institutional qualities of the two IOs is randomly assigned across respondents, but consistent across the four binary comparisons for each respondent to avoid confusion. The values of the institutional qualities are fully randomized, with two exceptions. First, respondents are never given the same value on an institutional quality in a comparison across two IOs. Second, respondents are never confronted with the same screen twice. Table 1. Institutional qualities varied in the experiment The organization works to… - protect human rights - promote public health - reduce poverty - promote free trade - ensure peace and security - combat climate change The organization … - has limited power over member countries - has some power over member countries - has extensive power over member countries Information about the organization’s decision-making… - is public - is partially public - is confidential In the organization’s decision-making… - citizens have a say - NGOs have a say - all countries have an equal say - only the powerful countries have a say The decisions of the organization… - benefit all countries equally - benefit some countries more than others The decisions of the organization… - solve most important problems - solve some important problems - solve few important problems

q24.value: not applied, since not considered necessary for previous, similar experiments

attributes.title: Can Celebrities Reduce Prejudice? The case of Mohamed Salah A pre- analysis plan

q1.value: Can Celebrities Reduce Prejudice? The case of Mohamed Salah A pre- analysis plan

q2.value: Ala' Alrababa'h | William Marble | Salma Mousa | Alexandra A. Siegel

q5.value: The authors are grateful to the Institute for Research in the Social Sciences at Stanford University and the Immigration Policy Lab for funding this project.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: We attempt to examine whether Mohamed Salah has had an effect on reducing Islamophobia and anti-immigrant attitudes in the UK as well as the specific mechanism in which any effect would have worked.

q16.value: We estimate the effect of portraying Salah as successful/failure and religious/character treatment on views toward Muslims and immigrants among Liverpool fans.

q17.value: By providing respondents with vignettes that emphasize particular aspects of Mohamed Salah using a factorial design.

q19.value: >2000 people (We are using facebook ads so it is unclear exactly how many we will get)

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The survey uses pairwise comparisons to generate novel indices of how Americans perceive attributes of 100 different risks. The attached preregistration file describes two studies that I intend to base on this survey. One explores why Americans prefer the government to spend more money fighting some risks relative to others. The other explores why Americans are more polarized in their beliefs about some risks relative to others.

q16.value: See attached preregistration and analysis plan.

q17.value: See attached preregistration and analysis plan.

q25.value: June 1 for full study; June 22 for modification to design

attributes.title: Aid for Peace: The Effect of Foreign Aid on Violent Conflict in Africa

q1.value: Aid for Peace: The Effect of Foreign Aid on Violent Conflict in Africa

q8.value: Registration after researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Though there are an abundance of well-designed and intentioned aid programs, there is a surprising dearth of evidence that these programs achieve one of their top goals: to deter violence. Quantifying the effects of foreign aid on violence has proven frustratingly difficult. Scholarly work tells us about foreign aid and its effects on civil war and about foreign aid to governments, but much foreign aid doesn't go through a foreign government and should not affect civil war. The effects of aid given to governments are unlikely to be the same as the effects of aid subnationally. This study uses subnational, geocoded data for aid programs and for violent conflict. I match locations that receive aid programs with very similar locations that do not receive aid programs and observe the occurrence of violence over the next 5 years.

q16.value: I have competing theories, with one predicting that foreign aid will increase violence and one that foreign aid will decrease violence. The mechanisms of these two theories produce hypotheses that can be tested empirically. I believe that aid could prevent violence through one of three mechanisms: (1) a direct, attitudinal change, (2) improving livelihoods & offering alternatives to violence, (3) producing a more open & inclusive political system. We are most likely to observe an attitudinal change with Peace aid, alternatives to violence with Economic aid, and a more open & inclusive political system with Governance aid. Aid could also increase violence through one of four mechanisms: (1) add resources to an ongoing conflict, (2) increase the value of resources, making them worth fighting over, (3) destabilizing local economies, or (4) general program mismanagement. If aid increase violence by adding resources to an ongoing conflict, we should only see violence increases in places that already had violence. If aid increases the value of resources, that should only occur with economic aid. If aid increases violence by destabilizing economies we should see the effect when an aid program leaves an area. And if aid increases violence through program mismanagement, we are most likely to see this in places that are already violent, places with many competing societal groups, and with peace and security aid.

q17.value: Geographic locations that receive aid programs will be matched with geographic locations that do not receive aid programs. For the location receiving aid, the observation will be the first year that an aid program is present. The locations are matched on conflict history over the previous decade, conflict history in the year before the aid program, sub-region of Africa, and 5-year time window. A location cannot be matched with its past or future self. For looking at the mechanisms (3 for an aid-->peace connection, 4 for an aid-->violence connection), the comparisons will differ. When the mechanism involves specific sectors of aid, the matches will be with places that receive no aid and places that receive aid from that specific sector. When the mechanism is conditional on the presence of violence, the matched places will have at least one violent event in the previous decade. When the mechanism is aid causing violence when the aid program leaves, the matches will be with places that receive no aid and places in which an aid program just left. The matching analysis then uses linear regression within matched blocks to determine the average effect of aid on violence.

registration_responses.q1: Aid for Peace: The Effect of Foreign Aid on Violent Conflict in Africa

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: What motivates qualified citizens to run for higher office? This project implements a survey experiment on a novel population of local and state elected officials. Using a conjoint survey experiment, we randomly vary several institutional and electoral features --- including salary, opponent characteristics, and fundraising burden --- to assess their impact on respondents' willingness to run for higher office and the "scare-off" effect associated.

q16.value: Average marginal component effect of several electoral/institutional features of a hypothetical election on respondents' willingness to run and their self-assessed win probability. We expect: 1. the position's salary will have a positive marginal effect on interest in running and ambiguous effect on self-assessed win probability 2. higher fundraising burdens will depress interest in running and self-assessed win probability 3. more experienced opponents will depress interest in running and self-assessed win probability 4. more ideologically extreme opponents will increase interest in running and self-assessed win probability 5. negative campaign environment will decrease interest in running and have ambiguous effects on self-assessed win probability

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

We expect: 1. the position's salary will have a positive marginal effect on interest in running and ambiguous effect on self-assessed win probability 2. higher fundraising burdens will depress interest in running and self-assessed win probability 3. more experienced opponents will depress interest in running and self-assessed win probability 4. more ideologically extreme opponents will increase interest in running and self-assessed win probability 5. negative campaign environment will decrease interest in running and have ambiguous effects on self-assessed win probability

attributes.title: Strategic Discrimination in the Democratic Presidential Primary

q1.value: Strategic Discrimination in the Democratic Presidential Primary

q5.value: I gratefully acknowledge excellent research assistance from Blair Read.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This study is part of a series of experiments on strategic discrimination in politics. This study aims to show that strategic discrimination changes the way subjects evaluate real-world candidates, not just hypothetical candidates in fictional experiments. Specifically, the study tests whether different strategic messages cause subjects to evaluate white and/or male candidates as having a better chance of beating Donald Trump in 2020.

q16.value: 1. When asked to estimate the percentage of swing-state voters who would not vote for a woman or a black person for president, subjects will engage in strategic discrimination against black candidates and female candidates. 2. When told that support from white voters is the key to winning swing states, subjects will engage in strategic discrimination against black candidates (defined as Kamala Harris and Cory Booker). 3. When told that support from male voters is the key to winning swing states, subjects will engage in strategic discrimination against female candidates.

q17.value: Subjects will view the names and photos of the top 8 Democratic presidential candidates according to current polling (Biden, Sanders, Buttigieg, Warren, Harris, O’Rourke, Booker, and Klobuchar). Then, they will be randomized into one of three treatments (or no treatment, for the control group). Next, they will be asked to select and rank the three candidates with the best chance of beating Donald Trump in 2020. They will drag and drop names into a ranked list. They will be instructed that the person in the #1 position should be the candidate with the best chance of beating Trump; the person in the #2 position should be the candidate with the second-best chance of beating Trump; etc. Then, the dependent variables will be binary measures assessing whether at least one female candidate is included in this top 3 ranking and whether at least one black candidate is included in this top 3 ranking. I will also measure the probability that a subject’s top 3 ranking includes 100% white men.

q19.value: At least 4000 subjects divided equally into 3 T & 1 C. We are screening to include only subjects who voted in 2016, not for Trump, and want to see Trump beaten in 2020. That number could up to 5,000 if a more than expected meet the above criteria.

attributes.title: Relationships of Local Development: Traditional authorities and state leaders in rural Latin America

q1.value: Relationships of Local Development: Traditional authorities and state leaders in rural Latin America

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In rural Latin America, relationships between mayors and leaders of traditional institutions of communal landholding play an important role in shaping development outcomes. When cooperation occurs, mayors and traditional authorities are able to leverage their respective strengths to provide more and better public goods. Yet, such cooperation does not always occur with important implications for within-district inequality. The research associated with this pre-analysis plan investigates the decision of community leaders to support some mayoral candidates over others. Community leaders vote for candidates that they expect 1) to reciprocate electoral support with benefits and 2) to address contingent demands that arise during the mayor's term in office. I hypothesize that a sense of trust and reciprocity is best proxied by candidates' membership in a traditional community. Candidates need not be from the community of the traditional authority to receive support. Simply being from a community, as opposed to owning private property, is a sufficient proxy for trust and reciprocity that plays an important role in structuring the decision-making calculus of traditional leaders. This question contributes to a longstanding literature on the interaction of state and traditional institutions (Lerner 1958, Huntington 2006, Diaz-Cayeros et al. 2014, Cramb and Willis 1990, Baldwin 2015). Specifically, it seeks to add to a recent and growing scholarship on the relationship between traditional authorities and politicians, focusing largely on the role of traditional authorities as brokers for politicians (de Kadt and Larreguy 2014; Baldwin 2013). Under these models, traditional leaders support the candidates who can offer them resources and guarantee their survival. Yet, when are these promises credible? I argue that in Latin America shared membership in a traditional institution plays an important role in determining the degree to which traditional authorities trust mayoral candidates to address their concern and reciprocate support once in office. The findings of this project may also have important implications for intra-district inequality in rural Latin America. If community leaders systematically support candidates from communities, and communities comprise a large enough proportion of the electorate to consistently elect these candidates, then we might expect communities to disproportionately benefit from municipal resources. Conversely, and as seems to more often be the case, if communities vote in blocs yet comprise a small proportion of the electorate, communities may receive unequal access to municipal resources.

q16.value: I expect that community leaders decide to vote for candidates who can credibly commit to addressing community leaders' demands and/or reciprocating community leaders' electoral support. Traditional communal landholding institutions in rural Latin America, especially Mexico and Peru, are characterized by traditional norms of reciprocity, where individuals help each other today with the expectation that they will be helped, if needed, tomorrow. Such traditions are only rarely associated with other forms of land tenure. Thus, candidates who are from communal landholding institutions are seen as more likely to share these norms of trust and reciprocity. Therefore, when a candidate is from a traditional community, they are more likely to receive support from community leaders than when they are not identified as a member of a community. Localism (i.e. membership in the same community as the community leader) is expected to exacerbate a shared sense of trust and reciprocity. Thus, candidates who are from the same community as the community leader are expected to be viewed even more favorably. These effects are expected to be stronger for current presidents than ex-presidents, as collaborations with mayors are more salient for current presidents than former ones. H1: Community leaders will be more likely to support candidates from their communities over those candidates who are not from their communities. [Localism and shared community membership] H2: Community leaders will be more likely to support candidates who are from a community over candidates who are not from a community. [Community membership] H3: Community presidents will express greater trust in a partner who is from a community than a partner who is not identified as being from a community. H4: The proposed effect specified in H2 should be greater for current presidents than former presidents, given that relationships of collaboration and coordination with the municipal government are more proximate for current presidents than for former ones.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be evaluated using two experiments embedded in an original survey of 200-300 current and former community presidents in Cusco, Peru. A conjoint experiment will be used to evaluate whether a candidate's membership in 1) a community and 2) the community president's own community affect the decision of community president's to support that candidate. I evaluate these traits against other candidate attributes, which include gender, party affiliation, and key campaign promise. I use a non-parametric regression estimator to obtain the Average Marginal Component Effect of community membership. I then measure the proposed "trust/reciprocity" mechanism through an experimental behavioral game. Using a trust game (see Berg et al. 1995), I measure how much money community presidents award to a fellow community member as opposed to a partner who is not identified as a community member. Given random assignment to treatment, I estimate a straightforward difference-in-means to analyze the outcomes.

registration_responses.q1: Relationships of Local Development: Traditional authorities and state leaders in rural Latin America
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: In rural Latin America, relationships between mayors and leaders of traditional institutions of communal landholding play an important role in shaping development outcomes. When cooperation occurs, mayors and traditional authorities are able to leverage their respective strengths to provide more and better public goods. Yet, such cooperation does not always occur with important implications for within-district inequality. The research associated with this pre-analysis plan investigates the decision of community leaders to support some mayoral candidates over others. Community leaders vote for candidates that they expect 1) to reciprocate electoral support with benefits and 2) to address contingent demands that arise during the mayor's term in office. I hypothesize that a sense of trust and reciprocity is best proxied by candidates' membership in a traditional community. Candidates need not be from the community of the traditional authority to receive support. Simply being from a community, as opposed to owning private property, is a sufficient proxy for trust and reciprocity that plays an important role in structuring the decision-making calculus of traditional leaders. This question contributes to a longstanding literature on the interaction of state and traditional institutions (Lerner 1958, Huntington 2006, Diaz-Cayeros et al. 2014, Cramb and Willis 1990, Baldwin 2015). Specifically, it seeks to add to a recent and growing scholarship on the relationship between traditional authorities and politicians, focusing largely on the role of traditional authorities as brokers for politicians (de Kadt and Larreguy 2014; Baldwin 2013). Under these models, traditional leaders support the candidates who can offer them resources and guarantee their survival. Yet, when are these promises credible? I argue that in Latin America shared membership in a traditional institution plays an important role in determining the degree to which traditional authorities trust mayoral candidates to address their concern and reciprocate support once in office. The findings of this project may also have important implications for intra-district inequality in rural Latin America. If community leaders systematically support candidates from communities, and communities comprise a large enough proportion of the electorate to consistently elect these candidates, then we might expect communities to disproportionately benefit from municipal resources. Conversely, and as seems to more often be the case, if communities vote in blocs yet comprise a small proportion of the electorate, communities may receive unequal access to municipal resources.

Traditional communal landholding institutions in rural Latin America, especially Mexico and Peru, are characterized by traditional norms of reciprocity, where individuals help each other today with the expectation that they will be helped, if needed, tomorrow. Such traditions are only rarely associated with other forms of land tenure. Thus, candidates who are from communal landholding institutions are seen as more likely to share these norms of trust and reciprocity. Therefore, when a candidate is from a traditional community, they are more likely to receive support from community leaders than when they are not identified as a member of a community. Localism (i.e. membership in the same community as the community leader) is expected to exacerbate a shared sense of trust and reciprocity. Thus, candidates who are from the same community as the community leader are expected to be viewed even more favorably. These effects are expected to be stronger for current presidents than ex-presidents, as collaborations with mayors are more salient for current presidents than former ones. H1: Community leaders will be more likely to support candidates from their communities over those candidates who are not from their communities. [Localism and shared community membership] H2: Community leaders will be more likely to support candidates who are from a community over candidates who are not from a community. [Community membership] H3: Community presidents will express greater trust in a partner who is from a community than a partner who is not identified as being from a community. H4: The proposed effect specified in H2 should be greater for current presidents than former presidents, given that relationships of collaboration and coordination with the municipal government are more proximate for current presidents than for former ones.
registration_responses.q17: The hypotheses will be evaluated using two experiments embedded in an original survey of 200-300 current and former community presidents in Cusco, Peru. A conjoint experiment will be used to evaluate whether a candidate's membership in 1) a community and 2) the community president's own community affect the decision of community president's to support that candidate. I evaluate these traits against other candidate attributes, which include gender, party affiliation, and key campaign promise. I use a non-parametric regression estimator to obtain the Average Marginal Component Effect of community membership. I then measure the proposed "trust/reciprocity" mechanism through an experimental behavioral game. Using a trust game (see Berg et al. 1995), I measure how much money community presidents award to a fellow community member as opposed to a partner who is not identified as a community member. Given random assignment to treatment, I estimate a straightforward difference-in-means to analyze the outcomes.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This project examines the interactions between female empowerment and economic empowerment in the Arab world. We hope to assess whether employment can empower women in household decision making through access to income. We also analyze the barriers to female labor force participation in the region by investigating women's labor market preferences.

q16.value: We hypothesize that women who contribute more to a shared pool of resources via employment will have a greater influence on a mixed pair's choice of insurance plan. Two mechanisms underly this hypothesis. First, earning income raises women's efficacy, making them more likely to confront patriarchal norms of who decides how household money is spent. Second, men are more likely to become deferential towards women when women contribute more resources to their shared pool.

q17.value: We test these hypotheses through a lab in the field experiment. After randomly assigning endowments from an effort task, we will pair participants and have them bargain over which insurance policy to invest their shared pool of earnings. We hypothesize that women who contribute more to the shared pool will have a greater influence on the pair's choice of insurance plan. We operationalize influence through the difference between an individual's insurance policy preferences and the pair's final insurance policy choice. We also measure influence through observing and recording participants' behavior (who spoke more, who seemed more engaged) when deciding their pair's insurance plan. We test are mechanisms that women who earned more in the effort task are more efficacious, and more respected by men, through survey questions following the bargaining scenarios. With regards to women's labor market preferences, will will administer a brief survey to a different population of women which asks them to compare and choose among hypothetical job opportunities. These hypothetical job opportunities contain a range of attributes pertaining to wages, employer services (daycare, transportation, space for prayer) and gender dynamics (whether women are required to work alongside men),

q19.value: 224 participants for the lab in the field experiment; 300 for the employment survey.

q27.value: The Center for Strategic Studies at Jordan University

attributes.title: Contextual differences in the perception of thermal comfort scales – a large-scale international questionnaire study

q1.value: Contextual differences in the perception of thermal comfort scales – a large-scale international questionnaire study

q2.value: Marcel Schweiker | Rucha Amin | Susanne Becker | Joon-Ho Choi | Chungyoon Chun | Stephanie Gauthier | Runa T. Hellwig | Gesche Margarethe Huebner | Jungsoo Kim | Meng-Chieh Jeffrey Lee | Di Mou | Karin Schakib-Ekbatan | David Shipworth | Despoina Teli

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Scales are widely used to assess the personal experience of thermal conditions in built environments. Most commonly, thermal sensation is assessed, mainly to determine whether a particular thermal condition is comfortable for individuals. A 7-point thermal sensation scale has been used extensively, which is suitable for describing a one-dimensional relationship between physical parameters of indoor environments and subjective thermal sensation. A first assumption related to the usage of the 7-point scale is that the distances between individual labels are equidistant. However, past research questions such assumption. A second assumption is that the middle three votes of the thermal sensation scale refer to thermally comfortable conditions. This assumptions is the basis for the relationship between predicted percentage dissatisfied (PPD) and the predicted mean vote (PMV) and was used to establish acceptance levels for the adaptive comfort models, Again, previous studies have shown individual and contextual differences not supporting this assumption.

q16.value: The objective of this international questionnaire study is to reveal differences in the perception of thermal comfort scales due to effects related to context (geography/culture/language, climate, season) and groups of individuals (males/females) in order to improve the reliability of the scales interpretation. The main research questions are: 1. Are the distances between the verbal anchors of a) the thermal sensation scale and b) the thermal comfort scale, and c) the acceptance scale perceived (by students) as equidistant? 2. Is the assumption true, that the three middle votes of the thermal sensation scale can be considered as comfortable? 3. Which part of the comfort scale is considered as acceptable? 4. What is the relationship between the verbal anchors of the thermal sensation on the one hand and those of the thermal comfort scale and thermal acceptance scale on the other hand? 5. Are there systematic and significant differences in the allocation of verbal anchors on the thermal sensation scale due to cultural (countries (languages) involved), and/or other seasonal differences? 6. Are there systematic and significant differences between the verbal anchors perceived as comfortable (being preferred/ acceptable) due to contextual (country, season) differences? 7. Is the theoretical relationship valid under real conditions?

q17.value: The research questions will be addressed by means of a questionnaire study. The main analysis consists of three steps, (1) descriptive statistics, (2) analysis of patterns through Latent Class Regression (LCR), and (3) the analysis of influencing factors on the membership in one class.

q18.value: Germany, UK, Sweden, China, Taiwan, Australia, USA

q19.value: The survey will be conducted in each country in two seasons. There will be a minimum of 50 samples for each season and country.

attributes.title: Public Opinion on Electricity Supply: Evidence from Uttar Pradesh

q1.value: Public Opinion on Electricity Supply: Evidence from Uttar Pradesh

q2.value: Brian Blankenship | Jason Chun Yu Wong

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Survey experiment and traditional survey on public opinion about electricity supply in rural India.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1 (Entitlement). Respondents’ willingness to pay more will be negatively related to their levels of entitlement. Hypothesis 2 (Trust). Respondents’ willingness to pay more will be positively related to their levels of social trust. Hypothesis 3 (Collective Cost). Respondents’ willingness to pay more will be negatively related to the collective cost required. Hypothesis 4 (Collective Action). Respondents’ willingness to pay more will be positively related to the percentage of other households that have agreed to contribute. Hypothesis 5 (Delay in Service). Respondents’ willingness to pay more will be negatively related to the length of delay between payment and service improvement.

registration_responses.q2: Brian Blankenship | Jason Chun Yu Wong
